Description: THE OVERALL OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO ADVANCE MARINE ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) TECHNOLOGY FOR MONITORING OCEAN LIFE. THIS PROPOSAL HAS TWO RESEARCH COMPONENTS: 1) BENCHMARKS EDNA AGAINST TRADITIONAL TECHNOLOGIES BY INCORPORATING EDNA SAMPLING IN AN ONGOING MARINE FISH SURVEY CONDUCTED BY NEW JERSEY DEPARTMENT OF FISH & WILDLIFE IN RARITAN-SANDY HOOK BAY COMPLEX, NEW JERSEY; AND 2) DEVELOP GRAPHIC TOOLS FOR ANALYZING MARINE FISH COMMUNITIES USING EDNA AND TRADITIONAL SURVEY DATA, WITH INTENTION OF FACILITATING ECOSYSTEM-BASED FISHERIES MANAGEMENT. THIS PLAN FOLLOWS A CONCURRENT SAMPLING APPROACH SIMILAR TO THAT USED IN A PRIOR NEW JERSEY TRAWL-EDNA PROJECT. HOWEVER, THIS PROPOSAL INVESTIGATES A SHALLOW WATER ENVIRONMENT (MAXIMUM DEPTH 10 METERS) AND EMPLOYS MULTIPLE GEAR TYPES OTTER TRAWL, GILLNET, AND SEINE. THIS PROPOSAL DIRECTLY ADDRESSES NOAA LONG-TERM MISSION GOAL HEALTHY OCEANS BY FURTHERING EDNA AS A LOW-COST, LOW-IMPACT TECHNOLOGY FOR TIMELY AND ACCURATE MONITORING OF

IN ORDER TO FULLY EXPLORE OUR OCEAN AND DISCOVER THE LIFE THAT LIVES THERE, WE NEED TO SCALE UP OUR OBSERVATIONAL CAPABILITIES BOTH IN TIME AND SPACE. THE OCEAN REPRESENTS THE LARGEST HABITABLE ECOSYSTEM ON OUR PLANET, YET LESS THAN 5% OF THAT VOLUME HAS BEEN EXPLORED, AND NEARLY 50% OF MARINE LIFE ARE YET TO BE DESCRIBED. TO CLOSE THIS GAP, WE NEED TO INCREASE OUR CAPACITY FOR BIOLOGICAL OBSERVATIONS BY BUILDING DISTRIBUTED NETWORKS OF UNDERWATER SENSORS, VEHICLES, AND AUTOMATED DATA ANALYSIS PIPELINES. TO ADDRESS THIS NEED, UNDERWATER IMAGING, A MAJOR SENSING MODALITY FOR MARINE BIOLOGY, IS BEING DEPLOYED ON A DIVERSE ARRAY OF PLATFORMS. HOWEVER, TO SCALE THESE EFFORTS, WE NEED TO ENABLE AUTOMATION OF DETECTION AND CLASSIFICATION TASKS IN VISUAL DATA, AND TO DO SO IN REAL-TIME AND ON-BOARD TO ENABLE LARGE-SCALE DEPLOYMENTS OF UNCREWED VEHICLES. HERE THE TEAM PROPOSES TO DEVELOP ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE-INTEGRATED VEHICLE CONTROL ALGORITHMS USING BOTH DEEP LEARNING AND REINFORCEMENT LE

THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA BORDERLAND (SCB) HOSTS DEEP-WATER MINERAL DEPOSITS INCLUDING PHOSPHORITES, FEMN CRUSTS, AND RARE EARTH ELEMENTS SUCH AS YTTRIUM THAT ARE IN HIGH DEMAND AS FERTILIZERS AND FOR USE IN ELECTRONICS AND GREEN TECHNOLOGIES. THESE MINERAL CRUSTS PROVIDE UNIQUE HABITATS FOR DIVERSE YET POORLY CHARACTERIZED INVERTEBRATE AND MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES. WITH A RISING DEMAND FOR ACCESS TO DEEP-WATER MINERAL RESOURCES, THERE IS A NEED TO ACQUIRE BASELINE BIODIVERSITY MEASUREMENTS TO ESTABLISH TRADEOFFS ASSOCIATED WITH THEIR EXPLOITATION. IMPORTANTLY, THESE ECOSYSTEMS HOLD UNDETERMINED BIOPHARMACEUTICAL POTENTIAL THAT COULD DRIVE INNOVATIONS IN BIOTECHNOLOGY AND ADVANCES FOR HUMAN HEALTH. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO ASSESS THE BIODIVERSITY AND BIOPHARMACEUTICAL POTENTIAL OF BENTHIC MARINE INVERTEBRATES AND MICROORGANISMS ASSOCIATED WITH MINERAL-RICH, DEEP-SEA SITES WITHIN THE SCB BY ADDRESSING THE FOLLOWING AIMS: 1) GENERATE BASELINE BIODIVERSITY SURVEYS OF SPONGES, CORALS, AND MAC

THE TEAM PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A NEAR REAL-TIME, OCEAN THERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION (OTEC) POWERED, DIRECTIONAL PROFILING FLOAT THAT IS DESIGNED FOR PERSISTENT, LONG-ENDURANCE, DEEP-WATER OCEAN PASSIVE ACOUSTIC OBSERVATIONS. DEEP-WATER ACOUSTIC OBSERVATIONS ARE DIFFICULT TO OBTAIN DUE TO LOGISTICAL CONSTRAINTS INVOLVED WITH DEPLOYING AND RETRIEVING TECHNOLOGY IN OFTEN-REMOTE LOCATIONS, BUT OBSERVATIONS OF DEEP-WATER SOUNDSCAPES CAN PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO MARINE MAMMAL DISTRIBUTIONS, SEISMIC AND VOLCANIC ACTIVITY, ILLEGAL FISHING ACTIVITY, AND MORE. THE RESEARCHERS PLAN TO ADDRESS THIS DIFFICULTY BY INTEGRATING OCEAN HINDCAST MODELS TO INFORM DEPLOYMENT LOCATION AND NAVIGATE IN REAL TIME BY TAKING ADVANTAGE OF OCEAN CURRENTS. THEIR DESIGN ALSO INCLUDES OTEC TO POWER SENSORS ON THE FLOAT, REDUCING THE NUMBER OF TOXIC BATTERIES NEEDED AT SEA, AND THE CAPACITY TO ALLOW REAL-TIME ACOUSTIC PROCESSING FOR THE IDENTIFICATION OF COMPONENTS OF INTEREST. ANTICIPATED OUTPUTS FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE AN

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES USING TWO AUTONOMOUS UNDERWATER VEHICLES FOR EXPLORATION OF HYDROCARBON SEEPS, DEEP-WATER CORALS, AND MINERAL RESOURCES ALONG THE ALASKAN/ALEUTIAN EXCLUSIVE ECONOMIC ZONE (EEZ) AND MARGINS, IDENTIFIED AS A REGION CONTAINING MINERALS CRITICAL TO U.S. ECONOMIC AND SECURITY NEEDS. THE AUTHORS PROPOSE TO JOIN AN ALREADY-FUNDED, 18-DAY NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION PROGRAM ON THE R/V ATLANTIS AND  WITH HUMAN OCCUPIED VEHICLE ALVIN INVESTIGATING KNOWN SEEPS IN THE EEZ, THEN AIM TO LOCATE, CHEMICALLY CHARACTERIZE, AND MAP EXPRESSIONS OF UNKNOWN CHEMICAL ENVIRONMENTS AND BENTHIC COMMUNITIES; EMPLOY NEW SENSORS AND SAMPLERS, INCLUDING HIGH-RESOLUTION METHANE SENSORS AND A PUSH CORE SAMPLER; PRODUCE FINE-SCALE, 3-DIMENSIONAL SEAFLOOR RECONSTRUCTIONS AND MAPS FROM DOWN LOOKING 4K RESOLUTION VIDEO IMAGERY; AND GROUND TRUTH MULTIBEAM DATA. EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE ENGAGEMENT WITH NATIVE ALASKAN COMMUNITIES; HIGH RESOLUTION SEAFLOOR MAPS AND MOSAICS; DISCOVERY OF

RESEARCHERS AT FLORIDA ATLANTIC UNIVERSITY PROPOSE AN EXPEDITION ON THE R/V F.G. WALTON SMITH TO EXPLORE MARINE HABITATS SURROUNDING PUERTO RICO AND THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS WITH THE SPECIFIC GOAL OF IDENTIFYING MARINE ORGANISMS WITH BIOACTIVE NATURAL PRODUCTS THAT CAN BENEFIT PHARMACEUTICAL AND BIOMEDICAL RESEARCH TOOL PRODUCTION. PREVIOUS EXPEDITIONS HAVE HIGHLIGHTED AREAS OF RICH CHEMICAL BIODIVERSITY THAT THE AUTHORS PLAN TO EXPLORE USING MOHAWK, A REMOTELY OPERATED VEHICLE (ROV) SYSTEM WITH THE CAPABILITY TO COLLECT ORGANISMS SUCH AS SPONGES, OCTOCORALS, AND ALGAE. THEY IDENTIFIED THE GEOGRAPHICAL REGION AS AN AREA WITH MINIMAL EXPLORATION FOR BIOPHARMACEUTICAL POTENTIAL AND PLAN TO ESTABLISH A LONG-TERM RESOURCE FOR RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT THAT WILL INCLUDE FROZEN SPECIMENS, A CHEMICAL LIBRARY, A LIBRARY OF MICROORGANISMS, CRYOPRESERVED SPONGE CELLS, AND A DNA LIBRARY. IMAGERY, VIDEO, DATA, AND PHYSICAL SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED TO DOCUMENT THE EXPLORED HABITATS.

THE AUTHOR PROPOSES A PROJECT THAT UTILIZES EXISTING OPEN-SOURCE DATA AND PRIOR FIELD EXPEDITIONS IN NOAA THUNDER BAY NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY (TBNMS) TO DEVELOP AN AUTONOMOUS GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS) TOOL FOR PROCESSING MULTIBEAM SONAR DATA AND HIGHLIGHTING REGIONS OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL INTEREST. MACHINE LEARNING WILL BE USED TO DETECT SHIPWRECKS IN MULTIBEAM SONAR DATA FROM SURFACE VESSELS; GROUND-TRUTHED SHIPWRECK SITES AND SIMULATED DATA WILL BE USED AS TRAINING DATA. THE RESULTANT GIS TOOL IS INTENDED TO BE EASILY ACCESSIBLE FOR MARINE ARCHAEOLOGISTS AND WILL EXPEDITE THE PROCESS OF LOCATING ARCHAEOLOGICAL FEATURES IN MASSIVE DATASETS. DATA FROM TBNMS, A SITE WITH ALMOST 100 KNOWN SHIPWRECK SITES, AND NOAA OCEAN EXPLORATION WILL THEN BE FURTHER EXPLORED USING THE DEVELOPED TECHNOLOGY. EXPECTED PRODUCTS OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE SOFTWARE TOOLS DEVELOPED FOR DETECTING SUBMERGED ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES, A TUTORIAL ON MACHINE LEARNING IN THE OCEAN EXPLORATION SPH

THE AUTHORS PROPOSE A STREAMLINED, FULLY AUTONOMOUS METHOD OF LOCALIZING SEAFLOOR FLUID FLOW SITES USING AN AUTONOMOUS UNDERWATER VEHICLE (AUV). CURRENT METHODS REQUIRE MULTIPLE, SEQUENTIAL AUV SURVEYS; THE PROPOSED METHODOLOGY SEEKS TO ELIMINATE SEQUENTIAL SURVEYS THAT REQUIRE CLOSE SURVEILLANCE BY HUMAN OPERATORS. IN THE FIRST YEAR OF THE PROJECT, A VEHICLE SIMULATOR DEVELOPED BY THE JET PROPULSION LABORATORY (JPL) WILL BE USED TO VALIDATE DEVELOPED METHODOLOGY, INCLUDING AN ALGORITHM DESIGNED TO PROCESS AND SYNTHESIZE SENSOR DATA IN ORDER TO AUTONOMOUSLY DETECT AND TRACE HYDROTHERMAL PLUMES. DURING THE SECOND YEAR, THE AUTONOMOUS ALGORITHM WILL BE TESTED IN THE WATER AND SUBSEQUENTLY DEMONSTRATED AT A HYDROTHERMAL VENT SITE LOCATED IN PROXIMITY TO THE JUAN DE FUCA RIDGE. THE RESULTS FROM TESTING THIS TECHNOLOGY ARE EXPECTED TO PRODUCE A FULLY AUTONOMOUS ALGORITHM ABLE TO LOCALIZE SEAFLOOR FLUID FLOW SOURCES, INTEGRATED WITH AN AUV; PROVIDE A NUMERICAL FRAMEWORK FOR TESTING AUTONOMOU

PURPOSE: THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT COLLEGE PROGRAM WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE U.S. CONGRESS IN 1966 (AMENDED IN 2008, PUBLIC LAW 110-394) TO BE A HIGHLY LEVERAGED FEDERAL AND STATE PARTNERSHIP TO HARNESS THE INTELLECTUAL CAPACITY OF THE NATION'S UNIVERSITIES AND RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS TO SOLVE PROBLEMS AND GENERATE OPPORTUNITIES IN COASTAL COMMUNITIES. FOR OVER 50 YEARS, THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT COLLEGE PROGRAM HAS SUPPORTED COASTAL AND GREAT LAKES COMMUNITIES THROUGH RESEARCH, EXTENSION AND EDUCATION. SEA GRANT'S MISSION IS TO ENHANCE THE PRACTICAL USE AND CONSERVATION OF COASTAL, MARINE AND GREAT LAKES RESOURCES IN ORDER TO CREATE A SUSTAINABLE ECONOMY AND ENVIRONMENT.  THIS GRANT IS THE VEHICLE THROUGH WHICH MICHIGAN SEA GRANT LAYS OUT ITS PLAN TO IMPLEMENT THE GOALS LAID OUT IN IN THEIR FY2018-23 STRATEGIC PLAN, WHICH CAN BE FOUND AT: HTTPS://WWW.MICHIGANSEAGRANT.ORG/WP-CONTENT/UPLOADS/2020/10/MI-SG-STRATEGIC-PLAN_10212020_FINAL.PDF IN ADDITION TO REQUIRED GRANT PROGRESS REPORTING, THE REC

THE RECIPIENT OF THIS FUNDING IS SHIPS OF EXPLORATION AND DISCOVERY RESEARCH, INC. THE RESEARCH TEAM OF THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT A FOCUSED EXAMINATION OF THE DEEP-WATER AREAS AFFECTED BY THE WORLD WAR II 1944 BATTLE OF SAIPAN, THE LARGEST U.S. AMPHIBIOUS INVASION IN THE PACIFIC THEATER DURING JUNE AND JULY 1944. WITH THEIR MULTIDISCIPLINARY APPROACH, KEY DELIVERABLES OF THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE ARCHAEOLOGICAL, PHYSICAL AND CHEMICAL, AND BIOLOGICAL DATASETS BY APPLYING EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES AND IN SITU METHODOLOGIES INCLUDING LIDAR, MACHINE LEARNING (ML), CORROSION STUDIES, REMOTELY OPERATED VEHICLE (ROV) PHOTOGRAMMETRIC SURVEY, AND ENVIRONMENTAL DNA. THROUGH COMPREHENSIVE AND SYSTEMATIC SURVEY OF THE DEEP-WATER STAGING AND OFFSHORE SEADROME AREAS, THE PROJECT WILL EXPLORE, LOCATE, AND CHARACTERIZE THE UNDERWATER CULTURAL HERITAGE, GENERATING UNDERSTANDING FOR MANAGING AND PRESERVING THE FULL BATTLEFIELD. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO THE BLUE ECONOMY THROUGH REGIONAL INDUSTRIES,

THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS TO DEMONSTRATE THE SCIENTIFIC APPLICABILITY OF A NOVEL LOW-COST RESEARCH PLATFORM FOR DEEPWATER ECOLOGICAL SURVEYS WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY DEVELOPING MACHINE-LEARNING ALGORITHMS FOR AUTOMATED IMAGE PROCESSING OF DEEP-SEA CORALS THROUGH A COLLABORATION BETWEEN ENGINEERS AND MARINE ECOLOGISTS. THIS PROJECT INCLUDES (1) COMPLETING A NOVEL OPEN-SOURCE LOW-COST DEEPWATER AUTONOMOUS UNDERWATER VEHICLE (AUV); (2) PERFORMING OPTICAL IMAGING OF A DEEP-SEA CORAL BED WITH THE PROPOSED LOW-COST PLATFORM; AND (3) DEVELOPING MACHINE-LEARNING ALGORITHMS TO EFFICIENTLY ANALYZE THE IMAGE DATA. THE SURVEYS AND DATA GATHERING WILL TAKE PLACE AT THE MAKAPU'U PRECIOUS CORAL BED IN HAWAI'I. THE AUV HAS THE POTENTIAL TO DRASTICALLY INCREASE THE SCOPE AND ECONOMIC EFFICIENCY OF ACQUIRING OCEAN EXPLORATION DATA, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF MACHINE LEARNING METHODS TO HELP CHARACTERIZE DEEP-SEA CORALS WILL FACILITATE THE MORE EFFICIENT PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS OF LARGE VOLUMES OF DATA. THE RECIPIENT

PURPOSE: ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A PRIORITY RESEARCH TOPIC TO REBUILD DEPLETED FISH STOCKS TO MAINTAIN PRODUCTIVE FISHERIES IN THE UNITED STATES. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP A NOVEL QUANTITATIVE TOOL TO ESTIMATE FISH PRODUCTION ON ARTIFICIAL REEF HABITATS, AND FURTHER IDENTIFY BEST-PRACTICE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT OPTIMIZE MULTI-SPECIES FISHERIES ON ARTIFICIAL REEFS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE DEVELOPING AN INDIVIDUAL-BASED MODEL USING SOFTWARE R PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE TO SIMULATE PROCESSES THAT SIMULATE FISH PRODUCTION ON ARTIFICIAL REEFS. THIS PROJECT ALSO AIMS TO IDENTIFY FISHING REGULATIONS THAT OPTIMIZE MULTI-SPECIES FISH PRODUCTION.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE RESULTS THAT INFORM ARTIFICIAL REEF DEVELOPMENT FOR ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT, SPECIFICALLY BY QUANTIFYING THE EXTENT TO WHICH THREE PROCESSES, CONSUMER-PRODUCER FEEDBACKS, RECRUITMENT, AND MORTALITY, INTERACT TO CONTROL FISH PRODUCTION ON ART

THE AGES WORKSHOP WILL BRING TOGETHER RESEARCHERS AND STAKEHOLDERS FROM ALL THE DIFFERENT FIELD ACTIVITIES OCCURING DURING THE SUMMER OF 2023 INCLUDING AEROMMA+CUPIDS, GOTHAAM, EPCAPE, AND STAQS TO DISCUSS SCIENCE GOALS, PLANNING, AND COORDINATION. THE AGES CONFERENCE WILL BE A HYBRID MEETING. MOST ATTENDEES WILL BE ENCOURAGED TO ATTEND IN PERSON. THE VIRTUAL COMPONENT WILL BE LIMITED, BUT STILL ALLOW RESEARCHERS AND ESPECIALLY STAKEHOLDERS, WHO MAY NOT BE ABLE TO ATTEND THE MEETING IN PERSON, THE ABILITY TO PARTICIPATE BY GIVING PRESENTATIONS, LISTENING TO ALL DISCUSSIONS INCLUDING THE BREAKOUT SESSIONS, AND ASKING QUESTIONS THROUGH A CHAT APPLICATION LIKE SLIDO.

PURPOSE:  THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ENHANCE THE REALISM OF GLOBAL OCEAN AND SEA ICE SIMULATIONS BY IMPLEMENTING A VERSION OF THE MODULAR OCEAN MODEL VERSION 6 (MOM6) AND SEA ICE SIMULATOR VERSION 2 (SIS2) MODEL ON A HIGHER RESOLUTION GRID THAN WHAT IS TYPICALLY USED IN CLIMATE STUDIES. THE GOAL IS TO MAKE THIS MODEL ACCURATE ENOUGH FOR TIDAL PREDICTION, WHICH WILL REQUIRE CALIBRATION OF THE MODEL'S RESOLUTION-DEPENDENT PARAMETERIZATIONS. THE INTERACTIONS OF TIDES WITH LOWER- AND HIGHER-FREQUENCY PROCESSES, SUCH AS INTERNAL WAVES AND SUBSURFACES TURBULENCE, LEAD TO TRANSPORTS OF ENERGY AND TRACERS WHICH ARE NOT ACCURATELY REPRESENTED IN PRESENT-DAY OCEAN AND CLIMATE FORECASTING SYSTEMS. DEVELOPING MORE ACCURATE REPRESENTATIONS OF THE TIDAL PROCESSES WILL ENABLE THE DEVELOPMENT OF CLIMATE REANALYSIS AND FORECASTING SYSTEMS IN THE FUTURE.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO BUILD AND VALIDATE ONE OF THE COMPONENTS THAT WILL ENABLE PROGRESS TOWARDS AN OCEAN SIMULATION SYSTEM

DESPITE THEIR CRITICAL ROLE IN MARINE ECOSYSTEMS, THE ECONOMY, AND OUR FOOD SUPPLY CHAIN, MIDTROPHIC-LEVEL ANIMALS LIKE ZOOPLANKTON AND SMALL FISH , WHICH ARE BOTH PREDATORS AND PREY, ARE AMONG THE LEAST UNDERSTOOD ANIMALS IN THE OCEAN. CURRENTLY, RESEARCHERS LACK THE TOOLS THEY NEED TO EFFECTIVELY STUDY THESE ANIMALS AT LARGE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES. TO ADDRESS THIS GAP, THIS RESEARCH TEAM WILL DEVELOP NEW WAYS FOR LONG-TERM, LARGE-SCALE DATA COLLECTION RELATED TO THESE IMPORTANT RESOURCES. OPERATING IN JUAN DE FUCA CANYON OFFSHORE WASHINGTON, THE TEAM WILL EQUIP AUTONOMOUS UNDERWATER GLIDERS WITH ACOUSTIC DOPPLER CURRENT PROFILERS (ADCPS). THESE INSTRUMENTS ARE USUALLY USED TO MEASURE THE SPEED AND DIRECTION OF OCEAN CURRENTS, BUT THEY CAN ALSO BE USED TO DETECT AND QUANTIFY ANIMALS AS THEY MOVE THROUGH THE WATER COLUMN. THE TEAM WILL DEMONSTRATE HOW ADCPS CAN BE USED TO SIMULTANEOUSLY COLLECT NEEDED PHYSICAL AND BIOLOGICAL DATA IN A MANNER THAT IS EASIER AND CHEAPER THAN CURRENT

SEAFLOOR GAS SEEPS ARE BOTH A SIGNIFICANT ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCE AND THREAT. GIVEN THAT MANUAL VISUAL INTERPRETATION OF WATER COLUMN SONAR IMAGERY IS COSTLY, TIME-CONSUMING, AND INCONSISTENT, THE RESEARCH TEAM AT MISSISSIPPI'S STATE UNIVERSITY WILL DEVELOP A MACHINE LEARNING BASED SOFTWARE SYSTEM TO AUTOMATICALLY DETECT AND SEGMENT GAS SEEPS IN AN EFFICIENT AND COST-EFFECTIVE MANNER. THEY WILL USE AN EXISTING DATABASE OF OVER 800 MANUAL VISUAL SEEP DETECTIONS TO TRAIN AND VALIDATE THE SYSTEM, AFTER WHICH THEY WILL APPLY THE SYSTEM TO THE ARCHIVED MULTIBEAM SONAR WATER COLUMN DATA AT NOAA NATIONAL CENTERS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL INFORMATION (NCEI) TO LOOK FOR THE PRESENCE OF SEEPS, AND DEPOSIT THE FINDINGS AT THE NCEI HOSTED SEAFLOOR FLUID EXPULSION ANOMALIES DATABASE. THEY ANTICIPATE A BROAD APPLICATION OF THIS TECHNOLOGY BY ORGANIZATIONS AND PROJECTS INVOLVED IN OCEAN MAPPING AND DISCOVERY SUCH AS SEABED 2030. THE KNOWLEDGE TO BE GENERATED BY THIS PROJECT ABOUT SEEP ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTI

UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON AND RUTGERS UNIVERSITY PROPOSE TO DEVELOP UNDERWATER ACOUSTIC TECHNIQUES USING AN AUTONOMOUS UNDERWATER VEHICLE (AUV) AND COORDINATED MULTIBEAM SONARS TO EXAMINE HYDROTHERMAL VENTS THAT ARE INCREASINGLY RECOGNIZED FOR THEIR SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC POTENTIALS BUT INSUFFICIENTLY CHARACTERIZED. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL TEST THE METHOD AS A TOOL OF MEDIUM-SCALE SEAFLOOR CHARACTERIZATION THAT CAN BE FURTHER APPLIED TO LARGER AUV-BASED SURVEYS. THE OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO DETECT EVEN LOW-TEMPERATURE HYDROTHERMAL DISCHARGE AND MAKE THREE-DIMENSIONAL AND QUANTITATIVE PANORAMIC OBSERVATIONS WITH HIGH SPATIAL RESOLUTIONS AND AREAL COVERAGE RATES. THE SYSTEM WILL BE FINALLY DEMONSTRATED AT AN ACTIVE VENT NEAR THE JUAN DE FUCA RIDGE AND/OR AXIAL SEAMOUNT OFF THE OREGON/WASHINGTON COAST AND THE PROJECT WILL GENERATE BASELINE DATA FOR POLICYMAKERS TO ASSESS HYDROTHERMAL ACTIVITIES WITHIN AREAS OF NATIONAL INTERESTS.

TO GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF METHANE AS SIMULTANEOUSLY A POTENT GREENHOUSE GAS IN A WARMING OCEAN, A NATURAL ENERGY SOURCE FOR THE MARINE ECOSYSTEM, AND A POTENTIAL RESOURCE FOR AUTONOMOUS UNDERWATER VEHICLES (AUVS) OCEAN EXPLORATION, THIS PROJECT INVOLVES THE COLLABORATION OF THREE UNIVERSITIES TO LOCATE AND CHARACTERIZE THE EPHEMERAL BUT WIDELY-DISTRIBUTED SOURCES AND SEEPS OF METHANE IN THE CASCADIA MARGIN (CM) OFF THE COAST OF WASHINGTON AND OREGON. FUNDING TO UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON WILL RESULT IN THE USE OF RELATIVELY INEXPENSIVE AND SMALL-CLASS "DEEP TWO-PERSON-PORTABLE" AUVS MOUNTED WITH CALIBRATED SONARS TO CARRY OUT CHARACTERIZATION AND MONITOR EMISSION VARIABILITY OF THE DETECTED SEEPS. THE OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO EFFECTIVELY QUANTIFY METHANE BUBBLE FLUXES WITH HIGH ACCURACY AT A LOWER OPERATING COST, ADVANCE THE OVERALL SAMPLING STRATEGIES OF AUVS FOR OCEAN MAPPING AND DISCOVERY, AND ENHANCE KNOWLEDGE OF THE REGIONAL ECOSYSTEM AS WELL AS THE B

WITH ALASKA HAVING THE LARGEST COASTLINE BUT ALEUTIAN WATERS BEING ONE OF THE LEAST UNDERSTOOD AREAS IN THE ENTIRE EXCLUSIVE ECONOMIC ZONE OF THE UNITED STATES, THIS ISLAND CHAIN IS A GEOGRAPHICAL PRIORITY FOR OCEAN EXPLORATION. SPECIFICALLY, RESEARCHERS AT EAST CAROLINA UNIVERSITY AIM TO FILL IN THE GAP OF UNDERWATER ARCHAEOLOGICAL WORK RELATED TO THE WORLD WAR II NORTH PACIFIC THEATRE BY EXAMINING THE NEGLECTED BATTLE OF ATTU AND ITS MARITIME BATTLEFIELD, THEREBY COUNTERACTING THE ANONYMITY AND ERASURE OF THE HISTORICAL BLOODSHED AS WELL AS THE TRAUMATIC EXPERIENCES OF THE INDIGENOUS PEOPLE OF SASIGNAN. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL SURVEY THE SEAFLOOR USING SYNTHETIC APERTURE SONAR (SAS), AN EMERGENT FORM OF MARINE REMOTE SENSING TECHNOLOGY, CONDUCT BATHYMETRIC TESTING USING AN UNCREWED UNDERWATER VEHICLE, AND SUBJECT SONAR TARGETS TO REMOTELY OPERATED VEHICLE PHOTO SURVEYS FOR GROUND-TRUTHING, IDENTIFICATION OF WRECK SITES, AND BIOLOGICAL CHARACTERIZATION. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES FUNDING TO UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS FOR AN 8-DAY EXPEDITION IN THE SUMMER OF 2023 ON BOARD THE RESEARCH VESSEL SIKULIAQ TO ASSESS PELAGIC ANIMAL DIVERSITY AND DISTRIBUTION IN THE DEEP WATERS OF THE GULF OF ALASKA, THE SHELF OF WHICH SUPPORTS ONE OF BIGGEST COMMERCIAL FISHERIES IN THE U.S. IT WILL EXAMINE HOW PROGRESSIVE OCEAN WARMING, DECLINING OXYGEN CONCENTRATIONS, AND EXTENSIVE VOLCANIC SEAMOUNTS AFFECT THE WATER COLUMN HABITATS AND THE VERTICAL RANGE OF FAUNA, SPECIFICALLY GELATINOUS ZOOPLANKTON AND MICRONEKTON. BUILDING ON THE EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE OF NORTHERN GULF OF ALASKA LONG TERM ECOLOGICAL RESEARCH NETWORK (NGA-LTER), THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL CARRY OUT REMOTELY OPERATED VEHICLE VIDEO SURVEY, HI-RESOLUTION IMAGING AND MAPPING, CHANNEL ACOUSTICS, IN SITU AND NET-BASED SAMPLE COLLECTION, AND DNA METABARCODING ANALYSIS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH SPECIES INVENTORIES AND CHARACTERIZATION OF THE AREA, RELATE THEM TO VARIOUS ENV

THE PROPOSAL PROVIDES OER WITH THE OPPORTUNITY TO EXPAND OUR EFFORTS TO ENGAGE THE OCEAN EXPLORATION COMMUNITY AS REQUIRED UNDER OUR STATUTORY MANDATE AT 33 U.S.C. 3403, INCLUDING OUR ABILITY TO IDENTIFY NATIONAL OCEAN EXPLORATION PRIORITIES THROUGH COMMUNITY INPUT, TO COLLABORATE WITH ACADEMIC AND TECHNICAL EXPERTS TO DEVELOP NEW CONCEPTS OF OPERATION FOR OCEAN EXPLORATION, AND TO CONDUCT REGULAR OCEAN EXPLORATION FORUMS REQUIRED AT 33 U.S. 3403
PIVOTING TO VIRTUAL OCEAN EXPLORATION EDUCATION POST-COVID: EXPAND ON VIRTUAL AND HYBRID ADAPTATIONS DEVELOPED IN PANDEMIC ENVIRONMENT TO INCREASE ACCESS TO OCEAN EXPLORATION EDUCATION

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP GUIDANCE FOR PLANNERS AND COMMUNITIES IN THE GREAT LAKES ON THE USE  OF CLIMATE DATA, SCIENCE, AND INFORMATIONAL RESOURCES AS THEY RELATE TO LAKE LEVEL-FLOOD RISK AND  EQUITY TO BUILD LONG TERM CLIMATE RESILIENCE. THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD UPON THE 2017-2019 NOAA FUNDED RESEARCH PROJECT "INCORPORATING CLIMATE SCIENCE TO HELP COMMUNITIES PLAN FOR CLIMATE EXTREMES" AND DEVELOP SUPPLEMENTAL GUIDANCE FOR THE ALREADY PUBLISHED GUIDEBOOK "USING  CLIMATE INFORMATION IN LOCAL PLANNING: A GUIDE FOR COMMUNITIES IN THE GREAT LAKES." THIS  PROJECT WILL DEVELOP TWO NEW CHAPTERS FOR THE GUIDEBOOK, THE FIRST FOCUSING ON LAKE-LEVEL  VARIATION AND FLOOD RISK, AND THE SECOND FOCUSING ON DATA, TOOLS, AND RESOURCES FOR COMMUNITIES  SEEKING MORE EQUITABLE OUTCOMES.
